questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the areas in the histology of lymph nodes show small-unchallenged B cells 
surrounding pale-staining germinal centres?
questions.explanation:
The mantle zone of the lymph nodes shows small, unchallenged B cells surrounding pale-staining 
germinal centres. Structures in a follicle: • Germinal centre - round/oval zone containing pale-staining cells surrounded by darker cells. • Mantle zone - small, unchallenged B cells surrounding pale-staining germinal centres. • Marginal zone - Light zone surrounding follicles; contains post-follicular memory B cells derived 
after stimulation of recirculating cells from T-cell-dependent antigen.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a B lymphocyte marker?
questions.explanation: CD13 is an antigen of monocyte/macrophage and not B-cell.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is false regarding Non-Hodgkin lymphoma?

options.a: It involves multiple peripheral lymph nodes
options.b: Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are rarely involved

questions.explanation:
Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are commonly involved in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). 503 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which is the most common non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults?
questions.explanation:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma 
(NHL) in adults and children over the age of 15 years, worldwide and in India. Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common NHL in children under the age of 15 years.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a B-cell neoplasm?
questions.explanation: Anaplastic large cell lymphoma is a T-cell lymphoma.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is the most common site for primary extranodal lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
The most common site for primary extranodal lymphoma is the stomach. The term primary extranodal non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (PE-NHL) refers to lymphomas that 
present with the disease at any organ or tissue other than lymph nodes or spleen. Gastrointestinal lymphoma is the most common form of primary extranodal lymphoma, 
accounting for 30%–40% of cases. The most common site involved is the stomach (60%–75% of 
cases), followed by the small bowel, ileum, cecum, colon, and rectum. Note: The most common site for extranodal non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) in AIDS is Primary 
CNS lymphoma.

questions.question: Question 7: Which lymphoid neoplasm is associated with the human herpesvirus 8?
questions.explanation:
Primary effusion lymphoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8). It is a rare type of diffuse large B cell lymphoma with lymphomatous effusions in pleural, 
pericardial, and abdominal cavities, but no tumor mass. Only one body cavity is typically involved. It is strongly associated with HHV8 and advanced HIV 
and usually EBV. It can also occurs in non-immunosuppressed patients, often the elderly.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is correctly matched with its associated etiological factor?
questions.explanation:
The correctly matched neoplasms with their associated etiological factor: • Extranodal marginal cell lymphoma - H.pylori infection (c) • Intestinal T-cell lymphomas - Gluten-sensitive enteropathy (d) • Anaplastic large cell lymphoma - Breast implants (b) 504
